children.name: about a1
children.definition: about more or less than a number or amount. ‘about’is the usual word to use in everyday english :
examples: it costs about $30 to get a visa.
there were about 50 people at the meeting.
the church is about a mile away.
it’s been about five years since i’ve seen linda.
the chance of men being born colourblind is about 1 in 12.

children.name: roughly b2
children.definition: roughly approximately - used especially when you are trying to give sb a general idea of the number or amount: đại khái, phỏng chừng
examples: a new kitchen would cost roughly $6,000.
the man was roughly my own age.
there were roughly 50 people there.

children.name: or so b1
children.definition: or soinformalabout – used after a period of time, a number, or an amount :
examples: 3 days/a minute/fifteen people etcor so
the journey takes an hour or so.
the baby usually sleeps for an hour or so after breakfast.
he suggested that i take a week or so off work.
there must be thirty people or so in the class.

children.name: odd x
children.definition: odd informal spoken use this after numbers in tens, hundreds, or thousands: khoảng
examples: a hundred/forty/thirty etc odd
‘how old do you think he is?’ ‘oh, i don’t know. seventy odd.’
it’s been 30 odd years since i last saw him.

children.name: give or take x
children.definition: give or take spoken use this when saying approximately what a number or amount is, when it may be a few miles more or less, a few minutes more or less etc: hơn kém
examples: give or take a few miles/a couple of minutes/a pound etc
the village is about fifty miles north of here, give or take a few miles.
he’s said to be worth $26 million, give or take a few million.
‘how long will the meeting last?’ ‘a couple of hours, give or take.’

children.name: at a guess b1
children.definition: at a guess spoken approximately, especially when you do not know the correct number or amount and are guessing what it is: tôi đoán
examples: ▪ at a guess, i’d say around 3000 people took part in the demonstration.
▪ it was a cold night. about two or three degrees at a guess.
▪ ‘how much will it cost?’ ‘a hundred and twenty pounds, at a gue

children.name: approximately b1
children.definition: approximately more or less than a number or amount.approximatelyis a little more formal than about and is used especially in written english:
examples: approximately 30% of the community is polish.
each disk stores approximately 144 pages of text.

children.name: approximately a large amount or number
sth in the region of c1
children.definition: sth/swh in the region offormalabout – used with very large numbers or amounts : đâu đó khoảng
examples: last year he earned something in the region of $60 million.
it costs somewhere in the region of £100,000 to train a new doctor.
the business is worth something in the region of $25m.
the universe is estimated to be somewhere in the region of eleven billion years old.
a typical price would be somewhere in the region of £2,500 per person.

children.name: sth like c2
children.definition: sth like spoken: đâu đó khoảng
examples: smith is already something like $10,000 in debt.
in the usa something like 4000 such accidents occur each year.

children.name: estimated b2
children.definition: an estimated approximately that number or amount - use this when you have no exact or detailed figures on which to calculate the exact number: đâu đó khoảng, ước chừng
examples: an estimated 3000 people/one million pounds/90% of profitsetc
the event was seen on television by an estimated 250 million people worldwide.
an estimated 10% of new mothers suffer from severe depression
by the end of the month an estimated 1000 people had been killed and 42,000 left homeless.

children.name: some x
children.definition: some approximately that number or amount - use this especially when you think it is impressive or surprising: đến, cỡ
examples: some 100 people/50 years/2000 establishments etc
among the 11 factory sites across europe, some 2,600 jobs are to be eliminated this year.
he lectured at the institut pasteur for some 50 years.

children.name: or more
children.definition: used after a number or amount, when the total may be a lot more, and you want to emphasize that this is a large number or amount: hoặc hơn
examples: 5000 people/20%/9 days etc or more
how can you be tired? you slept for ten hours or more last night.
there were a thousand or more fans at the airport to welcome the band.

children.name: at approximately a particular time or date
about a1
children.definition: about especially us a little later or a little earlier than a particular time or date. ‘about’is the usual word to use in everyday english: khoảng chừng, xấp xỉ
examples: it’s two-thirty. they should be arriving about now.
the cathedral was completed in about the middle of the 16th century.
about six months ago he suffered a major heart attack.
round aboutespecially british
he left the house round about four o'clock
the job should be finished round about march next year.

children.name: approximately b1
children.definition: approximately a little later or a little earlier than a particular time or date.approximatelyis a little more formal than about or around and is used especially in written english: xấp xỉ, khoảng chừng
examples: the gate will close approximately two minutes before the train leaves.
tours start approximately every 15-20 minutes in summer.

children.name: some time a2
children.definition: some time at a time in the past - use this when you do not know exactly when or it is not important exactly when: vào khoảng
examples: some time after/before/around/between/in etc
▪ the burglary must have happened some time after 8:00 p.m.
▪ his third symphony was written some time between 1750 and 1753.
▪ the clinic was closed some time in the early nineties.

children.name: or thereabouts x
children.definition: or thereabouts use this after a time, date etc that is not exact, especially when it is not important to know the exact time, date etc: cỡ đó, gì đó
examples: at 10 o'clock or thereabouts/in the 1950s or thereabouts etc
they’re old apartments, built in the 1930s or thereabouts.
the book will be published in may or thereabouts.

children.name: circa x
children.definition: circaformalabout – used with dates a long time ago in the past : vào khoảng
examples: the house was built circa 1530.
the manuscripts date from circa 400 b.c.
a robert adam mansion, built circa 177
the picture shows tsar nicholas, circa 191

children.name: around a2
children.definition: around about a time – used when you are guessing :
examples: i’ll be there around 5 o'clock.
the bbc broadcasts around 2,000 radio dramas every year.
i picked sue up around eight o' clock.
i don’t remember the exact date of the party, but it must have been around the first of december.

children.name: roughly b2
children.definition: roughly/ˈrʌfli/
examples: gần như
▪ yes, that’s roughly the right answer.
vâng, đó gần như là câu trả lời chính xác
▪ as long as you know roughly how to do it, that’s fine.
đến chừng nào bạn biết làm gần như vậy, vậy là ổn rồi

children.name: more or less b2
children.definition: more or less if sth is more or less correct, it is good or correct enough to be accepted even if it is not perfect: hầu như, không ít thì nhiều
examples: what she says is more or less true.
‘did they have what you were looking for at the hardware store?’ ‘yes, more or less.’

children.name: sort of b1
children.definition: kind of/sort of informal spoken said when you think something is approximately right or true, but not exactly:
examples: ▪ it’s kind of circular-shaped, but not exactly.
▪ ‘did you finish your homework?’ ‘well, sort of.’

children.name: in the right ballpark x
children.definition: be in the right ballpark informal if you are in the right ballpark, what you have guessed is not exactly correct, but is close to being correct: nói gần đúng, đoán gần đúng
examples: ‘i’d think a project like this would take at least five years to complete.’ ‘not quite as long as that, but you’re in the right ballpark.’

children.name: be sth of c2
children.definition: be sth of a sthinformal used to describe a person or thing in a way that is partly true but not completely or exactly
examples: it came as something of a surprise.
he has a reputation as something of a troublemaker.
i have a biology question for you – i gather you're something of an expert.

children.name: vague
children.definition: /veɪg/  an explanation, promise, reason etc that is vague is not exact, but you think that it should be: mập mờ
examples: ▪ the doctor’s vague explanations only increased clara’s fears.
▪ i’ve only got a vague idea of what he wants for this project.
be vague about explain somethingin a vague way nói cái gì đó một cách mập mờ
▪ officials were vague about the number of weapons that were uncovered.
vaguely[adverb] mập mờ
▪ they murmured something vaguely when i asked how long they had been there.

children.name: hazy
children.definition: /ˈheɪzi/  a hazy memory, understanding, idea etc is not clear and not exact: mơ hồ
examples: ▪ she had a hazy recollection of being carried out of the room.
▪ the details are still a little hazy.

children.name: an approximate amount or number, time, etc
approximate b2
children.definition: approximate an approximate number, amount, or time is close to the exact number, amount etc, but could be a little bit more or less than itsyn rough opp exact: gần đúng, gần chính xác, xấp xỉ
examples: what is the approximate number of students in each class?
these percentages are only approximate.
the measurements are approximate, but i think they’ll do.
an expert could give you the approximate value of the painting.
approximate journey time to london is four hours.
registerin everyday english, people usually sayroughrather thanapproximate:
can you give me aroughidea of how much it would cost?

children.name: rough b1
children.definition: rough  approximately correct, and therefore not to be used for detailed or important work: xấp xỉ, gần đúng
examples: rough guess/calculation/estimate/indication
the report should give you a rough indication of the company’s stock market performance over the past year.
i’d say that the whole thing would cost you around $1000, but that’s just a rough estimate.
a rough sketch of the house
a rough translation
could you give me arough ideawhat time you’ll be home?
arough estimateof the cost
first do arough draftof your essay.

children.name: loose c2
children.definition: looseloose translation/interpretation/sense etca record, explanation etc of something that includes parts that are not exactly like what was said, written, or decided originally: phóng, đại khái
examples: this is only a loose translation of the original paper.
a looser interpretation of the law would lead to more convictions.
loosely[adv]
the term "empire' is often loosely applied to a federation of states.

children.name: ballpark figure x
children.definition: ballpark figure a number or amount that is approximately correct - used especially in business: con số gần đúng, áng chừng, phỏng đoán
examples: ▪ a ballpark figure for the cost of the construction is $4.5 million.
▪ a firm price hasn’t been set yet, but the ballpark figure under discussion is $3 million.
give sb a ballpark figure
▪ could you give me a ballpark figure?

children.name: approximation x
children.definition: approximation formal a number or amount that is approximately correct: con số xấp xỉ, gần đúng
examples: approximation of
an approximation of the total
a rough/crude approximation(= one that is not very exact )
could you give us a rough approximation of the cost?
a good/close/reasonable approximation
five thousand dollars seems to be a reasonable approximation of the actual cost.

children.name: or two c1
children.definition: or twoinformal
examples: approximately or a little more than
_i'll be with you inaminute or two.
_it'sagood year or two since we last met.

children.name: swh around b2
children.definition: somewhere around/between, etc.
examples: approximately; about
_somewhere between 900 and 1100 minor crimes are reported in this city every week.
_it will take us somewhere between three and four hours to get tomadrid.
_the company's annual turnover is somewhere around £70.7 million.

children.name: in a sense c1
children.definition: in a sense(alsoin one sense)
examples: thinking about something in one way, but not in every way
_she claims that the system is at fault and she's right, in a sense (= she is
partly right) , it could be improved.
